  • Hoping to Be Delighted by Apple

    Well it‚Äôs Apple iPhone event day and I feel conflicted.

    I‚Äôm really ready for a phone upgrade, I want to pass my current phone on to my wife1 so we can share Live Photos of my daughter, plus then she won‚Äôt have a terrible battery life. But I feel a bit nervous. I‚Äôm worried Apple won‚Äôt give me a reason to upgrade today.

    It‚Äôs a funny fear to have, that someone won‚Äôt make you want to give them money. No doubt I‚Äôll change my mind as they could probably just release a phone with a new processor and I‚Äôd want to upgrade but at the same time I‚Äôm really not sure where they go next with smartphones.

    Personally, I‚Äôm intrigued by the idea of a foldable phone and I suspect something like a Samsung note that can unfold into a small square tablet with stylus could be very interesting. But that doesn‚Äôt seem on the horizon for Apple. Then again it is not unlike Apple to quietly work away at something for a while and then suddenly release it upon the world.

    Regardless, I‚Äôll be watching the keynote (or more likely checking the summary afterwards) and hoping that there will be a surprise or two that I don‚Äôt see coming. Apple are often good at delivering those sweet hardware and software features that delight and perhaps the iPhone Xs will see some new delight.

    1. For the record, I‚Äôd buy her a new phone but she is very resistant to spending money on herself.¬†↩

  • Education Needs to Be Inconvenient

    Education needs to be inconvenient

    Education needs to be inconvenient because it relies on effort and discomfort to move us from where we were to where we want to be. The internet gives us more access than ever, and if we care enough, we can use that convenient access to explore the inconvenient places that we know we should be exploring.

    • Seth Godin

  • Protect your attention

    I made this sketch in my commonplace book about a week and a half ago and since then this idea has come up a few times for me (including the latest Episode of Hello Internet . That‚Äôs usually a sign to take notice of an idea, when it keeps coming up. It‚Äôs also part of the value of a commonplace book, you can notice the themes and ideas that come up again and again and see patterns and connections emerging over time.

    Attention is one of our most valuable resources and yet nowadays it feels like it‚Äôs given away for so little. Even giving away your Email address for some freebie is an invitation to take some of your attention.

    I‚Äôve made a few changes recently to try and protect my attention more but I know that I both don‚Äôt stick to all of those changes and they don‚Äôt go far enough.

    • Focusing on longer and deeper content
    • planning silence
    • limiting disctration time

    They‚Äôve all helped but the issue persists. Today I disabled some more notifications, removed another couple of podcasts from my app and finally set some limits in the new screen time settings in iOS 12. I hope they‚Äôll help, but I know the attitude is the most important step.

    ‚Üí 7:30 PM, Sep 9

  • Steal Like The Decemberists

    Song Exploder - the Decemberists : once in my life

    As I was just playing it and playing it over and over again, it reminded me of one of these Yo La Tengo songs called ‚ÄúBarnaby hardly working‚Äù which is one of my favourite songs of all time. So we were playing it live and I felt moved one night to sing the last two lines of ‚ÄúBarnaby hardly working‚Äù, ‚Äúlays down by the river, face down by the river‚Äù.

    Colin Meloy

    I loved this episode because it‚Äôs such a great example of ‚Äústealing like an artist‚Äù. Referencing the influences that lead to the song but how this diverse group of influences lead to a completely different song that doesn‚Äôt sound like the influences at all.

  • On Writing Your Job on Your About Page

    This week I realised that I could add an about page to my Micro.Blog blog and it could be longer than the mini about desciption in my Micro.blog profile (thanks @simonwood). As I was writing it, I did the classic thing that I‚Äôve heard the folk at The minimalists podcast complain about. I used my job title to describe myself.

    In facts, I used my job title as my primary description of myself. This is the natural and expected course of action. When we meet someone new, one of the first few questions is usually ‚Äúand what do you do?‚Äù which really means _‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your job?‚Äù and potentially, ‚Äúhow much do you earn and are you worth my time‚Äù.

    Well, the second part is the highly cynical take from the minimalists which I somewhat agree with. At the same time, if you do a 9-to-5 job, the chances are you spend 1/3 of your day doing that thing (then a further third sleeping) meaning you probably do spend most of your time doing your job.

    My last job was a teacher, it‚Äôs a pretty well respected thing to include in your profile. People generally think teachers are okay but not necessarily useful for themselves.

    My new job is a title I really like, ‚ÄúContent Writer‚Äù which is a way to say ‚Äúcopywriter but we pay you less‚Äù and it reflects a lot of what I like doing, researching and write. But in truth, it‚Äôs not a full representation of my character and what I do.

    So I tried a different About page here, one that focuses on actions and personality traits I want to exhibit first rather than where my paycheck comes from. I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll revisit it and update it, but it‚Äôs a start.

    ‚Üí 3:16 PM, Sep 5

  • Evernote lost its CTO, CFO, CPO and HR head in the last month as it eyes another fundraise | TechCrunch

    Evernote lost its CTO, CFO, CPO and HR head in the last month as it eyes another fundraise | TechCrunch

    TechCrunch has learned and confirmed that in the last month, Evernote lost several of its most senior executives, including its CTO Anirban Kundu, CFO Vincent Toolan, CPO Erik Wrobel and head of HR Michelle Wagner beyond the usual attrition of engineers and designers.

    The departures are coming at a key time: we have also heard that Evernote is¬†fundraising, potentially in a down-round from its most recent (but now several years-old) valuation of $1.2 billion.

    Yikes! This is really not great news. I‚Äôve used Evernote for years and been a paying member for the last three. It‚Äôs not a perfect app/service, but it does the job and in the last year the company has really improved (aka, they stopped bugging me about workchat). Still, stuff like this suggests that things may not be so hot, I‚Äôd better look for an alternative and a way to move all my notes out.

  • But I was opposed to becoming ‚Äúmileage crazy‚Äù. Mileage craziness is a serious condition that exists in many forms. It can hit unsuspecting travellers while driving cars, motorcycles, riding in planes, crossing the country on bicycles or on foot. The symptoms may lead to obsessively placing more importance on how many miles are traveled than on the real reason for traveling. ‚Ä¶ A person must be very careful to not be overly concerned with arriving.

  • Thoughts on the film "Chef"

    I re-watched the film with my wife over the last two days. It‚Äôs a film I‚Äôve wanted to revisit for a while but I knew I needed a bit of time. There‚Äôs a few storytelling elements that I really love in the film.

    Here‚Äôs the super short summary

    • the critic at the start of the film is right.
    • Carl‚Äôs relationship with his son is the most important storyline
    • Restoring that relationship leads to his professional success
    • The final crisis is all of his own creating and echos the start of the film
    • He ends no longer needing the critics approval.

    The critic is right.

    Yeah, he‚Äôs blunt and rude with his criticism but he totally highlights Carl‚Äôs issues. He has no creative control (which Carl doesn‚Äôt realise at the start) and so his food is bland. Is he really a hater? I‚Äôve seen this online sometimes where unless someone applauds your every move, they are a hater. You can‚Äôt offer constructive criticism because any criticism means you are a hater. To be fair, the words the critic uses are attacking the character of Carl so maybe he is a hater‚Ä¶in this case.

    The storyline with his son is more important than his professional career

    His professional career brilliantly mimics his relationship with his son (and was something I didn‚Äôt note when I first watched). At the start, he is just going through the motions with his son just as he is going through the motions at work. The difference is that he wants to be more creative with his work, he just can‚Äôt. With his son, he doesn‚Äôt seem to want to put in the effort because he is distracted by work.

    The low point of his career is the low point of his relationship with his son. He goes viral on the internet, loses his job and cancels his plans with his son. This is the ‚Äúdark night of the soul‚Äù moment of the film, where he is directionless and doesn‚Äôt know what to do. He has realised his problems in his last job, lack of creative control and stagnation, but he now has no options so he pushes his son away? We all know its the wrong option but it is understandable. He feels useless and doesn‚Äôt want his son to see him like this (oh hi pride).

    By sorting out his relationship with his son, it leads to his work life improving.

    Taking care of his son leads to him getting the idea for his food truck, he‚Äôs been presented with the idea before, but now he accepts it after his relationship is improving.

    The final crisis is different from the typical ‚ÄúHero‚Äôs journey‚Äù

    The classic hero‚Äôs journey usually takes a different path, we usually have a bigger final conflict where the hero re-faces their old enemy. In Chef it is returning home. Carl starts to take the wrong path and pushes Percy away, but he changes his mind and this leads to our happy ever after ending.

    Carl no longer needs the critics approval, but gets it anyway

    This including the critic who tells Carl that he‚Äôs back on track. The best touch of this is that Carl no longer cares about the critic, he doesn‚Äôt need to impress the critic unlike the start of the film where he is dependent on his review. It helps to show his progress, but it isn‚Äôt as dramatic as the classic hero‚Äôs journey and facing the emperor on the death star.

    Useful storytelling ideas

    I really like the storytelling devices that Chef uses, some of the shots are great too. It‚Äôs not a high stakes thriller but it is a great feel good film.
